Anthropic built their own economic tracking system because government data moves too slowly to capture what AI is actually doing to jobs. So, think about how the government measures employment. The Bureau of Labor Statistic does surveys, compiles data, releases reports, and by the time you're reading those numbers, they're already months old. That system was designed for an economy that changed gradually. A factory closes, unemployment ticks up in that region, the data captures it 6 months later. Policy makers respond. That feedback loop worked fine when transformations happen over years. Anthropic has something different. They can see in real time which industries are using Claude, which specific tasks people are delegating versus augmenting, how that's shifting week to week. Daria mentioned that they can even break it down by state, by subtask within industries. That's a level of granularity the government just doesn't have, and most importantly, it's current. They're watching the economic diffusion happen live. The distinction Darian makes between augmentation and delegation is really important. Augmentation means that you're using AI as a tool. It makes you faster, but you're still doing the work. Delegation means the AI is doing the task and you're just checking the output. Or maybe not even that. Those two patterns have completely different implications for employment. And right now, you don't have good enough data on which one is winning. Anthropic is trying to figure that out. I think the bigger point here is actually about policy. Dario's argument is pretty simple. You can't make good decisions without good data. And if data you have is 6 months old and too broad to capture what's actually happening, you're flying blind. So Anthropic build their own system. Whether the government actually developed something similar or whether this becomes a model other companies follow, I don't know. But the fact that a private AI company felt the need to build this tells you something about the gap between how fast AI moves and how fast our measurement systems move.
